content: hi @T-compiler/meeting ; we’re starting our first non-planning steering meeting of 2022 now!

before we start the meeting itself, are there any

Announcements ?
I have one: I have beta- and stable-nominated PR #93426, which backports an LLVM change ...
my current gut feeling is that if this successfully bakes for a week on nightly, then it can be backported to beta, but it might be too risky to backport to stable

the reason I stable-nominated it is that, based on what I’ve seen with industrial deployments, I am worried that bugs like this (where the compiler itself segfaults) can block Rust release upgrades. People who are knowledgable can do things like turn off LTO to work around them, but I’m not certain everyone knows to do that.
Do you think we need to decide on the backport prior to next week's triage meeting?

pnkfelix said:

the reason I stable-nominated it is that, based on what I’ve seen with industrial deployments, I am worried that bugs like this (where the compiler itself segfaults) can block Rust release upgrades. People who are knowledgable can do things like turn off LTO to work around them, but I’m not certain everyone knows to do that.

and that would be the reason to backport to stable despite the risk?
no. I am now thinking that the risk outweighs that concern
but I just wanted to bring it up
OK :+1:
@Wesley Wiser ’s point is valid: Why am I bringing this up now, rather than watiing until thursday
it is because, with the stable-approvals yesterday, I was a little concerned that another point release might go out without us even talking about this
(It's fine to bring it up, just wanting to understand how urgent you think it is)
but, given that my current gut feeling is that we probably wouldn’t stable-approve this anyway, then the conclusion wolud be that there is no urgency
anyway, that’s all, I just wanted to point it out
(Also, 10 minutes ago that PR failed with a core dump from … compiletest ...
so … that seems bad… or at least, re-emphasizes risky …)

pnkfelix said:

it is because, with the stable-approvals yesterday, I was a little concerned that another point release might go out without us even talking about this

I think this is why we need something more than just approving stable backports prior to a release. It would be helpful to have a conversation with the infra team and let them know how important we think a particular change is and it would be also helpful if we had a heads up when a stable point release was going to be created, even if we didn't know what was going in it (ie, it doesn't affect us or some kind of CVE).
@simulacrum it would be really cool to look into whether we could do rr runs on those CI systems that support it.

Wesley Wiser said:

pnkfelix said:

it is because, with the stable-approvals yesterday, I was a little concerned that another point release might go out without us even talking about this

I think this is why we need something more than just approving stable backports prior to a release. It would be helpful to have a conversation with the infra team and let them know how important we think a particular change is and it would be also helpful if we had a heads up when a stable point release was going to be created, even if we didn't know what was going in it.

Yes, this seems true. We probably do need to have a bidirectional conversation here. The waterfall model for backport approvals doesn’t really work so well when it comes to stable backports
Okay. I think we can talk about this more on Thursday
lets move on to the topic I wanted to talk about at today’s meeting: our stack of P-high issues.
I’ve made a doc: https://hackmd.io/YY3u0dkURtiQHDVX0hEImA?view
what I suggest is that we take … 10 minutes? to look over it
Usual deal: click :book: when you start reading, and leave it clicked. Click :checkered_flag: when you are done reading.
(I recommend first glancing at the picture, then read the text, and then, if you like, dive back into the picture)
@pnkfelix that graph is beautiful
So, imo, every P-high issue should have a WG-* label
Most everything there labeled A-traits should probably be WG-compiler-traits labeled (too)
I’ll enqueue this as a high level topic
lets wait for everyone to finish reading before we dive in
is there some trick to making the picture/graph bigger, other than just zooming in in the browser?
Unfortunately not. I recommend printing to a PDF file
I should have done that for you all ahead of time. Still could I suppose
let me just do that now
oh, right. screen capture was what ended up actually working best for me. LOL
this is best I can do on short notice, sorry: image.png
ok, well, I can more or less read it now
details probably don't matter that much
(its possible that a different mermaid host would handle this better. hackmd fail.)
okay it looks like everyone is done reading

so, first: Are there any questions about the content of the text, in terms of what it says? Anything you didn’t understand? (Things you disagree with, we can get to in a moment. :lol: ). ((I’m playing with emojis as a way for people to collectively register feelings…)
(checkbox is no, right?)
Yeah, sorry. Check box :checkbox: is “I understood it."
Okay. This seems like fine time to throw in ideas about what you think should change or what matters.
I already transcribed Jack’s idea about policies for every P-high needing a WG assigned

Useful links:
P-high issues: https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues?q=is%3Aopen+is%3Aissue+label%3AP-high
"wg-" labels: https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/labels?q=wg-
and I put a few on myself: I’m vaguely concerned about the I-unsound stuff, and I just want to spitball ideas re A-liftimes
wait: Prefix-search works ?
oh, prefix search for seeing set of labels. Does it work for searching issues too...
Doesn't look like it
too bad
At least, you can't search "wg-"
right. I wonder if that’s a useful feature request for github
but you can add e.g. the wg-compiler-traits label
right. but we can’t trivially search for “All P-high issues with no WG-label on it"
correct
that’s okay though. That’s a search that one could do via github API
I suppose it would be nice to have "label groups"
which arguably is what I should have been doing instead of making pretty graphs
anyways, should we discuss?

For some reason, a lot of A-labels have at most one or two P-high issues associated with them: A-frontend, A-lint, A-inference, A-testsuite, etc

This might not be worth talking about, but this actually seems kind of expected to me. We have a huge number of A- labels and most of our P-high issues are concentrated in a few areas so the rest of the P-high issues are probably dispersed over the large set of area labels.

I'm not sure what this points to in terms of getting those issues resolved though. There are so many areas of the compiler that it's far too large a problem for only a few people to tackle.
@Jack Huey I am correct that there are some P-high issues that are tagged A-traits and are not tagged WG-compiler-traits, right?
i.e. the property you mentioned before is a goal we should aspire to, not a current status
https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues?q=is%3Aopen+is%3Aissue+label%3AP-high+label%3AA-traits
only two have the wg label

Wesley Wiser said:

For some reason, a lot of A-labels have at most one or two P-high issues associated with them: A-frontend, A-lint, A-inference, A-testsuite, etc

This might not be worth talking about, but this actually seems kind of expected to me. We have a huge number of A- labels and most of our P-high issues are concentrated in a few areas so the rest of the P-high issues are probably dispersed over the large set of area labels.

I'm not sure what this points to in terms of getting those issues resolved though. There are so many areas of the compiler that it's far too large a problem for only a few people to tackle.

let me add this as a topic

pnkfelix said:

i.e. the property you mentioned before is a goal we should aspire to, not a current status

yes!
It sort of goes back to my vision that every P-high issue gets assigned to a subteam
yes, okay
any other random thoughts for big topics before we dig into each one?
well, people can enqueue them in the doc if they want
lets start with Jack’s point then.
making sure that every p-high issue has at least the T-compiler label?
so that they show up in queries
oh, i took it to mean: every P-high issue should have a wg
not every P-high issue is under T-compiler
well, T-compiler as a fallback
or in addition
sorry, let me refine
just to make sure it shows up in the relevant queries and does not get lost
I took it to mean “every P-high and T-compiler issue should have a WG"
Some of these might actually be lang team questions ...
we don’t deal with e.g. T-libs-impl stuff here

P-high issues without a team label: https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues?q=is%3Aopen+is%3Aissue+label%3AP-high+-label%3AT-compiler+-label%3AT-libs+-label%3AT-libs-api+-label%3AT-lang+-label%3AT-core

Wesley Wiser said:

Some of these might actually be lang team questions ...

You mean some of the P-high issues are blocked on lang team stuff?

Jack Huey said:

P-high issues without a team label: https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues?q=is%3Aopen+is%3Aissue+label%3AP-high+-label%3AT-compiler+-label%3AT-libs+-label%3AT-libs-api+-label%3AT-lang+-label%3AT-core

thanks Jack!
all from last year
These should be easy enough to label as T-compiler
I do think these are all T-compiler, yes?
yes
So, I think it's a good idea to try and assign a wg to every p-high issue
lets go ahead and throw the T-compiler on them
I can do that
and this does underscore @mw ’s point
but for some things like linkage there is no WG that fits today
that things will fall through cracks if someone doesn’t periodically double check that “P-high with no team” list that @Jack Huey linked

mw said:

but for some things like linkage there is no WG that fits today

Right.
and furthermore, I’m not sure that every existing WG is doing cadenced triage of their P-high issues
so just saying “its assigned a WG” isn’t quite good enough
but in general, having a WG assigned will increase the chance that an issue gets taken care of, I think

pnkfelix said:

that things will fall through cracks if someone doesn’t periodically double check that “P-high with no team” list that Jack Huey linked

Maybe @WG-prioritization or @WG-triage can help out here?
or at least, we need to distinguish between WG’s that plan to churn through their P-high set
and WG’s that don’t plan to do that (for whatever reason, including lack of resources)
Yeah, this is a good point. I guess the point of having it assigned to a working group, is that there's always "someone" you can go ask "what's the status of this"
but yes, I think @Jack Huey ’s idea is a good one. Its just not a sufficient condition for what I want to achieve
But, I think in reality that probably is more difficult
Right. @Wesley Wiser pointed that out to me in a meeting yesterday

Jack Huey said:

pnkfelix said:

that things will fall through cracks if someone doesn’t periodically double check that “P-high with no team” list that Jack Huey linked

Maybe WG-prioritization or WG-triage can help out here?

there's an item in the weekly agenda preparation about ensuring proper labels.I can add one item for "orphaned" P-high

i.e., once there’s a WG assigned, then at the very least, T-compiler leads can do triage at some cadence, and reach out to the leads of each WG for an issue and ask if there’s an update or plan to address it.
yes
I don’t know what cadence is reasonable yet, but I think its doable
i.e., the same way that we plan ahead for a backport review during the six week release cycle
Or if the priority should be adjusted (up or down) for some reason that isn't obvious to the rest of us :smile:
Just having some label that says "this is the person/team that 'owns' this issue"
maybe the T-compiler leads should plan a P-high review at some cadence, maybe once every 12 weeks… ?

Jack Huey said:

Just having some label that says "this is the person/team that 'owns' this issue"

By owning - I mean "has the proper background knowledge to evaluate an issue"

where that review is mostly to go through and check: 1. does this have an owner (where an owner is either a WG or an individal), and then 2. reach out and say “hey, is there a plan for how/when you’re goint to address this…"

Jack Huey said:

By owning - I mean "has the proper background knowledge to evaluate an issue"

“evaluate” … does not necessarily mean “fix” ?
Well, fix would be great
but able to read it, understand its status, maybe double-check if it is still an issue?
of course, a fix would be great
But sometimes there may be blockers to fixing
Like, I know for many traits issues, the blocker is "we're waiting for Chalk"
right. and being able to fix is not the same as being able to identify blockers
correct
and potentially sketch out the dependency chain
okay
I like this.

@Wesley Wiser do you think a 12 week cadence is a reasonable starting point for a regular meeting (or short series of meetings) that goes through the P-high issues? I suppose an issue will be, if that is too long a time, then the set of P-high issues will grow rather than shrink over time
So basically every 2 releases?
that’s what I was thinking as a starting point, yeah
we could aim for something more aggressive
In a perfect world, that review would be pretty easy
That seems reasonable. I would also expect we would probably take that time to reassess if an issue is still P-high?
Yes, yes, definitely
it makes sense to couple the tasks, I think
(a bug that shipped in 1.20 and is still P-high cannot actually be high priority :laughing:)
Related question: What does P-high mean? There's a page out there I remember.

Wesley Wiser said:

(a bug that shipped in 1.20 and is still P-high cannot actually be high priority :laughing:)

wait, is there an example of that? A cursory search didn’t show one
https://forge.rust-lang.org/compiler/prioritization/priority-levels.html#p-high
arguably the work we’re describing is meant to be done asynchronously by WG-prioritization
but I’m assuming they don’t have either capacity or proper direction to carry out that task
Or just the background knowledge to properly evaluate
is that a fair statement, @apiraino ? I don’t want to be putting an unfair amount of work on WG-prioritization
I exaggerated but "#64340: 'Linking issue with Rust 1.37.0'". Still 2.5 years old now.

Jack Huey said:

Or just the background knowledge to properly evaluate

right. Though arguably, the task of pinging owners doesn’t need background knowledge
I guess that’s where it gets tricky to couple the re-evaluation of priority
anyway, I’m liking what we’ve got so far

pnkfelix said:

Jack Huey said:

Or just the background knowledge to properly evaluate

right. Though arguably, the task of pinging owners doesn’t need background knowledge

right!
next topic

pnkfelix said:

is that a fair statement, apiraino ? I don’t want to be putting an unfair amount of work on WG-prioritization

I /think/ workload is not the issue, rather how to frame some of the issues that are prioritized
(example: this one)
The I-unsound bugs

apiraino said:

pnkfelix said:

is that a fair statement, apiraino ? I don’t want to be putting an unfair amount of work on WG-prioritization

I /think/ workload is not the issue, rather how to frame some of the issues that are prioritized
(example: this one)

Let me actually enqueue that matter as a topic (we probably won’t get to it, but I don’t want it to be totally forogtten forwever…)
So, I think new I-unsound issues always get P-critical
and if existing issues weren't already released, they would too
okay
So I-unsound/P-high issues are sort of "special"
And probably indicate that we should be thinking about the "long-term" plan to fix them
I think the pinging process we’re describing
should hopefully yield a semblance of a set of plans
Agreed
and, at worst, will uncover cases that have no plan
which we can up priorty on, perhaps
I’m comfortable with that, I think
Sounds good
Next: A-lifetimes …?
I don’t know if there’s an answer for what to do about A-lifetimes or A-linkage that we can identify in this meeting
but again, the review process already described should hopefully identify owners
I think A-lifetimes issues probably fall under WG-nll
lets go with that
A-linkage...not sure
two A-linkage are assigned to me, one to @mw
A-linkage is kind of weird. It covers a ton of different linkers on different platforms. I get why we have it but it's almost as if we just had an A-OS tag instead of O-mac, O-linux, etc.
hunh
that’s an interesting point
maybe the grouping is just wrong then, in terms of what is needed to resolve those problems
that’s a really good point
at the very least, its an example of where my methodology of using the A-* labels goes wrongs
but that’s okay
teh plan is to assign everything to some WG
and maybe the cases that don’t have a WG
we (eventually?) force into triage every week
"wg-unassigned"?
so that we all get so goddamn bored of hearing about them
that we fix them

pnkfelix said:

we (eventually?) force into triage every week

I like that
I actually think that might have potential
next up

We have a huge number of A- labels and most of our P-high issues are concentrated in a few areas so the rest of the P-high issues are probably dispersed over the large set of area labels. I'm not sure what this points to in terms of getting those issues resolved though. There are so many areas of the compiler that it's far too large a problem for only a few people to tackle.
again, maybe identifying the WG will help here
and again, being forced to talk about them at every meeting
will annoy someone enough to fix it
maybe
I’m of course worried about sucking up meeting time
something we already struggle with
so I’ll probably want to invest some of my own time trying to burn these down
We could always just randomly (or on rotation) select an issue or two to mention
before I throw them into the agenda
"anybody up to fix this"
@Jack Huey yes, maybe. That doesn’t accomplish the “ugh i’m so bored of hearing about this I will now fix it"
but that might be an anti-pattern anyway
Okay, so start with just a couple issues on the agenda
Anyway, I think, much like how Ownership was the secret sauce that solves everything in Rust
Ownership may well be the secret sauce that solves things here too
(in terms of identifying WG owners, and accepting T-compiler as fallback owner, and acting accordingly.)
With that, our hour is up, and I have a firm committment to leave
Thank you all so much for a great meeting! This felt really good.
Have a great weekend, stay safe!
This was helpful
@pnkfelix if you want help finding/assigning owners, let me know
I can at the very least look through the issues and tag as wg-compiler-traits where needed
thanks @Jack Huey ! That would be great! If you could also double check that the P-assignment makes sense as you do that for the WG-compiler-traits issues, that would be good
(I assume WG-compiler-traits is named that because it is focused on how traits are implemented, and not on what their semantics are in terms of T-lang ?)
I think most (all?) of the wg labels are prefixed with the "parent" team
err, maybe not
really? news to me
I'm just going to change that
sounds like an excellent idea though
(except for WG’s that are cross-cutting)
as a side point, there are a few wg labels that are probably not relevant anymore
"WG-epoch"
I'll make it a point to also go through these

Jack Huey said:

pnkfelix said:

that things will fall through cracks if someone doesn’t periodically double check that “P-high with no team” list that Jack Huey linked

Maybe WG-prioritization or WG-triage can help out here?

@Jack Huey FWIW, WG-triage is really only for triaging pull requests that are going stale, and we don't have much capacity even for just that.

WG-prioritization triage issues that need prioritization, so it kind of makes sense to add this (standard disclaimer: I'm a member of the WG, I have no authority on anything). I'm not sure there's always a T-compiler WG that fits, but something could probably be worked out. Plus, apiraino is a miracle worker. :)

Jack Huey said:

So, I think new I-unsound issues always get P-critical

I mean, I-unsound issues are usually marked P-critical. But if it only hits a tier 3 target, or requires a nightly feature...

Wesley Wiser said:

https://forge.rust-lang.org/compiler/prioritization/priority-levels.html#p-high

Just to remind everyone, that page is kind of a vague outline. In practice, as far as I've seen, wg members tend to go off experience and gut feel.

pnkfelix said:

Wesley Wiser do you think a 12 week cadence is a reasonable starting point for a regular meeting (or short series of meetings) that goes through the P-high issues? I suppose an issue will be, if that is too long a time, then the set of P-high issues will grow rather than shrink over time

FYI for people who were interested in the P-high bonfire: I’m going to try to drive the process of going through the P-high issues in structured fashion in the #t-compiler > reviewing P-high issues 2022 (Q1) topic.

I know the proposal above was for a presumably synchronous meeting. My current thinking is that the initial set of P-high issues that we’re looking at right now is so large that it could do with one or two asynchronous pre-passes.

And in any case, the whole point is just to 1. establish owners (either WG’s or individuals) and 2. get updates on plan-of-attack, if any, for each issue for its respective owner. That totally sounds like something that can be done asynchronously.
